name: Cracker Barrel
description: Typical Cracker Barrel overnight. Very loud 10 pm to midnight then quiet as a graveyard until 5 am. Could barely hear the interstate. Also the fastest service I’ve ever had in a restaurant. Three pull through sites and a dozen plus back in class B friendly sites.

name: Next to gas station
description: Large gravel area next to highway and tongas station. Possible to hide behind trees. Lots of trash and road noise. We slept here because we left a river bank in the night because of rain. Around 5 other campers slept here as well

name: Disused road beside Sacramento River
description: This spot beats truck stop parking lots by a mile. Close to a road but quite quiet in the night. General noise by day. Not a lot of options around here so happy to find this place amongst giant eucalyptus trees.  It’s an old section of road beside the river that’s blocked off at each end. You can access it on a smooth dirt road. Short easy trip in. No one bothered me here for the whole time I was here.

name: North Fork River Camp Spots
description: Several established camp spots with fire rings that can fit up to a 35 foot trailer (estimated). Other parking spots where it looks like people have made makeshift fire pits. Pit toilets. No cell service with Verizon. Great river access.

name: Jens camp site kern
description: North of chimneys campground south of the JOHNSON Dale Bridge

name: Large Gravel Street Pull-Off
description: Gravel pull-off big enough for multiple cars or a couple of RVs. Beautiful view of Lake Whatcom and some hills. Right across the street from a park with restrooms. Best if you can block out your windows somehow if you decide to sleep overnight.

name: Lucas Park - COE
description: Lucas Park - Corp. of Engineers. Free for non-electric sites from mid Sept - mid May. Fantastic place - I’d recommend the far sites 80’s +. Nice Rocktown trail up the road is a must. Was here on Friday and Saturday nights - only saw a handful of people and believe I was the only one camping.

name: Frenchtown County Park
description: Primitive Camping Along the Mississippi River. No one here on a Thursday night in mid June. It does abut a railroad so there is train noise. Not a lot free in this area so beautiful but noisy for a night.

name: Large Gravel Pull-Off/Turn-Out
description: large turnout big enough to fit several cars or a couple RVs. beautiful view of Lake Whatcom and a restroom across the street. if you decide to sleep in your car here I recommend blocking out your windows

name: The Flat
description: A nice grassy, level spot at the foot of a mountain. It's up a slightly bumpy road, maybe 1800 feet in elevation gain. I pulled up a 20 foot TT, no problem. There are quite a few fire rings in the area, great views.

name: Camp 12
description: About a mile down from the top of the Buckhorn. It's a big site, plenty of room for big rigs or groups. There are numerous sites all up and down the wash. Cell service is weak. but you can get it on the south side of the site.

name: Otter Creek State Park
description: A nice park for camping, also has the RV dump for $10

name: Chevron water spigot
description: Water spigot and air at the back of the Chevron. Very welcoming to use with signs and everything. Free.

name: King Soopers
description: Open parking lot with almost no trees. I talked to the security and manager inside. The security man said they do not patrol this parking lot. The manager said I could park overnight and he would let the night manager know I was there. Very friendly and helpful. I actually found some of the biggest shade trees in town next to an unused retail space across the parking lot from King Soopers, next to Jimmy John's. Stayed all night and into the morning (with shade) with absolutely no issues.

name: Monongahela National Forest Dispersed
description:
2 large dispersed camping spots. One is a loop on a large creek. Other is a muddier spot on smaller creek. Muddier spot has better sun for solar. Could fit 2 campers/vans
 in muddier spot as well.

name: Monongahela National Forest Dispersed
description: Right next to a creek, has a campfire ring.

name: Boat Launch Coulee Dam
description: Beautiful space with lots of room and side roads overlooking top of dam.  We stayed just beside boat ramp. Super clean cathedral toilet. There is a no camping sign but no indication you can’t park overnight. 3 bars VZW LTE was fine. We felt safe with parking lot lights. Saw a wild deer. Beach in distance to lake. Highly recommended. No water - other than lake. No dumping either. Just self contained peace.

name: Burger King Weaverville
description: Free, unblocked wifi. Accessible from the parking lot.

name: Spin Cycle
description: Clean place, several size washers and free regular dryers. Pay with cash or credit card, no special card that you have to load

name: Walmart on Chastain Meadows off Ernest Barrett parkway
description: Super Walmart, connected restaurants, strip mall stores, gas station in parking lot, well lit at night. Semi trucks, RVs, stay here. My self many times since Dec21 in my van with no issues. Convenient location and access to even more things nearby like Town Center Mall, more restaurants, gas stations, and banks.

name: Stoney Gorge Campground
description:
Beautiful first come first served campground with around 25 sites currently open. Run by the Bureau of Land Reclamation (federal land). Pit toilets (with toilet paper!) and gravel sites with fire rings. Tent camping for the night was $15 paid by card at the kiosk out front. Can easily walk down to the reservoir to paddle board/kayak etc. 

This was an unexpected gem. Only downside was slightly noisy neighbors, but they quieted down once we talked to them. Beautiful stars and reservoir. Fairly close to Williams if you need to refill supplies.

name: I90 Rest stop
description: Beside the main building is a chain link fence with a red water spigot.

name: Hornsilver Campground
description: USFS campground. 7 sites with picnic tables, fire rings and bear boxes. Pit toliets and trash disposal. $20 night. At about 8,700 feet. Able to text with ATT service.

name: Blodgett Campground
description: 5 sites. No bathroom, water or trash disposal. Very little ATT service text only. Great views. Must pack out human waste. Free.

name: Water Spigot
description: threaded potable water spigot on the back of the marathon gas station.

name: Ice House
description: 25¢/gallon or 5 for $1 cold drinking water. Ice $4/bag.

name: Yellowjacket Lake Campground
description: Nice remote campground near small lake.  cost is $10 a night. In April there was still some snow on the road and the water had not been turned on yet.  Lake is great for padding around in a kayak. With my booster I was able to get a very slow Verizon signal if I was in just the right spot, so don't count on cell coverage.

name: Water Stop
description: This is a spring running through a pipe for filling your water jugs. lots of flow, filled my 5 gallon jug in less than 30 seconds. I have been told by the locals that it's safe, drinking water, but use your own discretion.

name: capitol view
description:
about 20 min from the road, no need 4×4.
no sign of 'no parking overnigth'.
a big place but not sure about big rig.
on bar of mobile service, sometimes it goes away.
great spot, really nice view, fire pit.

name: Swains Creek
description: Large flat lot off the side of the road. Posted camping allowed up to 9 days. Very little road noise. Supposed to be next to a creek but it's dried up at this time.

name: BLM Land near I40 and Loves Truck Stop
description: This is a decent find.  Turn off is a small road on the right just after passing Loves truck stop heading south.  Great Verizon coverage.  Distant highway and train sound In distance.  A handful of sites just after turning in.  Some even had trees.  I went a bit further out with my 2wd van but it gets soft - need to be careful for these more distance spaces.  Probably would bring anything bigger that a small class C or similar.  I probably wouldn’t bring a trailer in here.  A handful of other campers when I showed up.  Seems well established for overnighting.

name: State Land Hidden Alcove
description: A little climb to get here, so not recommended for those not wanting that, but very private. Pack it in, pack it out, please.

name: High Country Arena
description:
Located in the beautiful Sacramento Mountains of southern New Mexico, just 2 miles from historic Mayhill, New Mexico.

16 full hookup RV sites
4 Tent sites
Free WiFi is also available.

name: Road to Oregon Caves
description: Small gravel parking next to road to Oregon Caves, spent here one night. Enough space for a few RVs.

name: Bandits Overlook
description:
Great views and remote.
Recommend low roof vehicles due to many overgrown trees. Nothing major, but might scratch up larger vehicles (I choose violence). Good road/not too bumpy Several option along the road in and further up as well. 1-2 bars ATT- enough for YouTube etc…

name: Bandits Hideout
description:
Great views on a hilltop. 2-3 bars ATT.
This may be the same as the one nearby, but my gps shows a little different. Take forest rd 30, turn right slightly past the pin on the map, it’ll Y, I took the open gravel rd on the left upwards. Towards the top the trees grow in pretty bad. I choose violence and plowed through them. The top has just enough room for one van/small rig to park and barely turn around.

name: Water @ Pearrygin Campgrounds
description: There are several water spigots located through the campground. This particular picture of one is located directly behind the showers/bathrooms. Mostly for big water jugs. Probably not intended for RV fillups. I did see a RV dump station on property, and usually there’s water there. This park does require a Discover Pass. $10/day. $35/year. www.discoverpass.wa.gov

name: I-79 southbound, West Virginia welcome center
description: rest area, dumping station and water at the exit from truck parking

name: Clearings next to farmland
description:
Two tree clearings next to some farmland. Not 100% sure if this is private property or not, but the road ahead is grown over, so you could park on the road itself, which also may or may not be private property.

Semi-steep gravel road for a few meters. Big rigs are probably a no-go, but I had no problem going up slowly in my 2WD sedan. A lot of the area is a soft dirt, so be super careful, and watch the weather. It rained hard for me in the morning so I moved out of the dirt onto the gravel. I saw a tick or two in the forested parts, and a few spiders in the dirt. Otherwise bugs weren’t too bad, especially compared to the other site nearby (Brandywine track).

I know I’ve only written about the negatives so far but it’s a really nice, huge couple of spots, pretty quiet. 2 bars + LTE on T-Mobile. No promises it’ll be this empty in the future, there was some farm equipment sitting by the road but it seemed untouched for quite a while

name: Denali View Point Campground
description: View point with large parking for any rig. Supposed to pay but no envelope. It is in the Denali State Park.

name: Ashton park free water
description: Red spigot near the playground. Bring your hose. Free

name: Trails End Campground
description: Rustic Campground around small lake just east of Copper Harbor, Mi.

name: FR 356 Hilltop
description: Site is located off of an offshoot of 356. Main forest road was quite wet and rutted. Gained access in a high-clearance 4x4. Existing path to the top of the hill revealed spot withtwo fire pits present.

name: BLM LaVerkin
description: A wide open free area (BLM rules). Easy in and out, loads of space, easy for tents or big rigs. The borders are marked. All sorts of cell service too. Food, fuel and supplies are minutes away in LaVerkin. The area does get dusty on windy days. There are dozens and dozens of sites in this area. I have never not found one.

name: Into the Wild (Bus 142)
description:
"Bus 142" from the movie Into the Wild has been removed from its original location and is on display at the University of Alaska, it's in the Engineering Facility College.  It is under restoration and can be seen for free from Monday to Friday from 8am to 6pm. When the restoration is finished, it will be moved to the forest near the museum of the same university.

El "Bus 142" de la película Rutas Salvajes fue removido del lugar original y se encuentra en exhibición en la facultad de Ingeniería de la Universidad de Alaska. Está en restauración y se puede ver gratis de Lunes a Viernes de 8am a 6pm. Cuándo termine la restauración será movido al bosque cerca del museo de la misma universidad.

name: Sol Duc Potable Water
description: Free potable water beside the dump station

name: Hearthstone Lake
description: Decent sized parking area next to the lake. Two or three smaller pull in spots to be right on the lake! 1 -2 bars of Verizon LTE. Beautiful!

name: cemetery
description: there is water available after parking no mention if not drinkable

name: Commuter lot
description: Commuter lot right next to the metro - 24 hour max stay

name: Parking lot overlooking canyon
description: This parking lot is off desert view road - it overlooks the canyon. Doesn’t say no overnight parking - wish I slept here last night and could watch the sunrise from my bed

name: Teton Reservoir Rec Area
description: Decent AT&T service, very spotty Verizon service. There’s plenty of spots to park either by the water or up on a hill, however there were lots of people that were there the week I stayed. There are pit toilets and it’s BLM land so you can stay 2 weeks. There were also fire pits and picnic tables in some spots.

name: Middle Waddel Campground
description:
Established campground with host that requires check in. It is free with WA state discover pass. Stay is up to 14 days in a month. Pass is $33 for the season.

Paved easy gravel whole way in. Tons of RVs and 2wd cars with tents.

name: St. Lorenz Churchgrove Campground
description: Nice campground with great hosts. Showers, bathrooms, quiet and clean. Some sites have fire pits and picnic tables. Quiet hours enforced. Great place to stay.

name: National grassland Boondocking
description: its the gravel road running g between the boundary fence of National grassland and National Badland Parks. pulled into this gravel road about a mile interior. camped  on the side of gravel road, no one used the gravel road all night.. Ni idea what this access road is about. At the entrance of road there was a sign alluding to that road is only dry weather. Couple of spots on road were deep mud, did not use 4x4. 2 wheel drive would have made it thru sides also. In wet weather doubt 2wd will make thru these spots. RTT drivers pay attention  to wind direction, it can pick up at night. Great wifi on TMobil network.

name: Distillery
description: The owners of the distillery are wonderful! Stop in for a drink and bite and chat. They allowed me to Park in their lot in the back. lots of stealth parking in the area as well. great beer and wine gardens nearby as well. Pet friendly.

name: lane springs campground and day use area
description: beautiful wooded area with a spring running thru it. some of the 18 campsites have water access but there's a public area with a nice little swimming area and a row swing. several pit toilets and a few water hydrants (? potable) many picnic tables for day use too. cost for a single campsite without electric using the senior America beautiful pass is just $4!! $2 for day use for anyone

name: Chinook County Park
description: A nice roadside park with a hydrant next to the bathroom.

name: 40 Horse Cave
description: This is a very well maintained road to access the campsite. It is about 25 mi from Idaho Falls and a few miles of 2-lane gravel road along Wolverine Rd with easy back in access for a 30-foot travel trailer. This is a grassy flat spot with a small stream running behind the campsite. There's a fire pit and a creek crossing that is behind the site that has a 2-mile walking trail from camp. Half a mile to the west is a locally known cave called 40 horse cave. No cell service, easy access to other sxs trails from the camp site. Might be dusty in the summer depending on the wind direction.

name: Meadow campsite near Bear Lake
description:
Forest road 27 is mostly campsites nestled in the trees. This spot is an open meadow with 3 campsites about 100ft from each other. Just a short hike to Bear Lake. 

These might be the only campgrounds with enough visibility for Starlink.

name: Menard’s Propane
description: Propane filling station on the left side of the parking lot. It was $3.11 / gallon for RV’s. Go to the customer service desk inside and someone will come out and help you with it.

name: Madras Public Works RV Dump
description: Free dump provided by the city. There's a water spigot with a blue handle but a sign that says "non potable water."

name: vacant lot
description: vacant lot across from Walgreens. I called the local police department and asked where I could park overnight without issues and they suggested this lot would be okay for one night. I ended up staying two nights and had no issues. It's right on the main road so it's a little noisy.

name: Non potable water for tank
description: Water in a rest / picnic area. No overnight parking. Non potable. Can attach hose.

name: Versailles State Park
description: This a large Park run by the Indiana Department of Natural Resources. It has wide range of activity including a pool. This it’s not cheap. $9 just to drive in and another $31.00 for a tent site with electric only so the prices go up from there. But hey, it’s has big open spaces and RVs should have no issues. Wi-Fi is weak but functional. Showers with flush toilets as you would expect at that price.

name: Larger NF pull-off
description:
Large(ish) pull-of on National Forest Road that does not show up on map. 

Some road noise from down below, but only if it’s a loud vehicle going past.

HUGE potholes so be careful. I made it fine going slowly in my 20 ft. Skoolie. 

Semi-sunny for charging Solar.

Evidence of two dilapidated fire rings. 

2-3 bars T-Mobile service.

name: Hartman Rocks, McCabe entrance
description: A lot less people camp at these sites, most coming in from the other entrance. This is the McCabe entrance and is much easier than the Kill Hill entrance. Great for large set ups and groups. And 2wd vans. Different views, not as rocky, more like rambling hills. It is just as beautiful. Read the other reviews of Hartman’s Rocks. Amazing place. One close vault toilet, very clean. Metal fire rings and picnic table.

name: BLM land
description: One of many pull-offs off the road. This particular spot is pretty close to the road, but totally blocked from view by trees. BEAUTIFUL view of the mountains. I tried a couple of other spots and it was a little hard to find a good flat spot, and this one was as flat as I could find (and still a little slanted). Road was unexpectedly busy (a car every couple of minutes), and there was quite a bit of trash around. There’s also some sort of grave here as well 😮 I think for a dog? Overall I did like this spot for the views and easy access (no need for high clearance or 4-wheel). High altitude so much cooler than Vegas. No service. I would stay here again!

name: Right off the road
description: Short climb, only for pickups & high clearance vehicles. 200m off the road. Up above the traffic, road noise but totally worth it, with stunning views of the mountains & rolling tundra. Enough room for 6 trucks

name: Salmon Camping by the River
description: 10-12 sites. Pay host $5. On the river. Iron bridge is a little noisy. Saw a family of otters swimming up stream and a couple of deer in the far bank.

name: Lippincott Pass
description:
From the 'Racetrack', avoid this unmaintained, steep pass with narrow, slanted turns and rocks big enough to get stuck on. The first few hairpins look OK, but there is no turning around and the bottom part is downright dangerous. No towing service.

If you came here from the Ubehebe Crater, consider driving back, or ignore the warning at 'Teakettle Junction' about deep sand through Hidden Valley and drive that (only if you have a decent 4x4!). The consequences of falling over on Lippincott Road are graver than getting bogged down in sand in Hidden Valley.

name: Confusing sign
description: This sign has a list of open or closed roads, but these roads are not contiguous. So, where it says that Scotty's Castle Road is closed, that does NOT mean that Death Valley is unreachable from here.

name: Cement creek campground
description:
Nice campsite 
About 15 sites 
Hiking trails
Bike trails 
More for small campers and tents 
Along the creek 
Fire pits with grills 
Bathrooms 
Firewood for sale but plenty of free wood in the woods  

4$ day use 
16$ over night camping

name: SW Clear Lake Shoreline
description: multiple dispersed spots with fire pits. some lakeside. road ends after sites but there's plenty of room, maybe 10+ spots. large pothold but high clearance probably not needed some spots are on shore right next to lake, others in tree.

name: Fall Creek Campground (USFS)
description:
Great FS campground. Campground is nicely wooded, we really can't see campsites that we are next to.

Fire ring, picnic table, charcoal grill at campsites.

Good Verizon coverage. And now that it is getting more popular, not a good option for Starlink.

name: Walmart
description:
Needed van repairs that was going to take 3 days till the shop could get me in.
Went inside Walmart and asked if I could stay the duration of the time and with out hesitation they welcomed me and said I could stay they have trucks, cars, RV’s, vans and travel trailers all the time.  They also said as long as I am respectful of the property and do not park in disability spots.

name: 6 mile sno-park
description: big paved lot with room for multiple rvs.

name: Bridger-Teton National Forest Camp #24
description: Bridger-Teton National Forest Camp Site #24

name: Terre Haute, Indiana. Little League Sports Complex.
description: Very large baseball playgrounds. Very Quiet. Quite desert.

name: Secluded forest road
description:
Unused forest road, which has become blocked by a massive fallen tree. The road is still about 200m long. I slept in my rooftop tent, and parked my vehicle on a pullout near the tree.

There’s not much space to turn around at the end, so anything bigger than a 4x4 would be very difficult

There’s a road that can be seen through the forest, which is also very quiet, 5 cars during the night. No one came up this road or bothered me, only 2 dirt bikes in the morning, who waved and moved on. We had a very quiet night. There are no “no trespassing” signs.

name: Tomahawk Park
description: Nice RV oriented spot, city run and super reasonable prices. Quiet and easy to get to

name: Buchanan State Forest - Jerry Road
description:
Jerry Road SH-017 -
The website states tent or vehicle camping up to 7 days with a permit that you call for and they will email you a form to fill out that can take up to 3 business days. Nice gravel road, only site available on this road. Quiet. Ranger comes through once in while and an occasional local. Site is right along the road. There is no spot for a tent. The site is unattended and is just filled with raspberry, strawberry, huckleberry, fern etc. Where there is grass it is blended and on a slope. Where it is flatter becomes a mud puddle when it rains. Once temps hit 75 the black flies, flies, mosquito, etc are more than abundant. So much that day hikers have decided not to return until cooler. The site is in full sun  They mention a stream, it across the road and another down the road, each apx 125' into the woods/down the road but it is no more than ankle deep, sometimes running underground. I have seen a unique bird, one rabbit, one deer, one box turtle and appears there is a bear.
There is highway and plane noise but both quiet enough.
My Cricket phone usually works. Don't always have access for more than text/call. Usually a reboot helps.
After 6 quiet days we headed out due to temps and bugs. The site has 2 pieces of toilet paper so pretty good. No water, garbage or tables. Has a makeshift fire ring. Wood can be tough to find as locals get it. I will give this spot 2 stars and won't use it again.

name: street parking
description:
4 hour street parking near museum.
Mon to Sat 9am to 8pm
free sundays.
NO signs for NO overnight parking

name: Cooks Beach
description: Dirt road ending on Cooks Beach on the Delaware Bay. No nearby houses. Can get buggy so be prepared.

name: Cloud Climbing Railroad RV Park
description: Small RV park with full hook ups, excellent WiFi  and a shaded courtyard with hammocks and hammock chairs.

name: Red Canyon
description: A large flat pullout, about 2.5 miles in, off gravel road. Room for multiple campers and big rig too. Sunny, no shade,  fire ring. AT&T 3 bars LTE. Road east for all cars at this time. Minor washboards

name: Cracker Barrel
description: Easy overnight. Next to a 24hr gas station. Called and asked, attendant said 'all good'! Very quiet through night on a Tuesday.

name: Vitus Gas Station Laundromat
description: Cheap laundromat. Shower is $2.50. coffee hut outside, attached quick stop has snacks. Free WiFi and TV.

name: Off rt 9
description: nice area with multiple spots to camp for the night.  T-mobile - 3 bars LTE.  Verizon - 2 bars LTE.

name: East Boulder Community Center
description: Communal shower in the men's locker room. $11 for a day pass or $9 if you live or work in Boulder.

name: Snowed Inn RV Park, Campers, & Tents
description: Full Service Hookups available with 30/50 amp electricity and water and sewer at sites. Some sites appear to be water and electric only. Also grassy area for tents. On-site laundry, showers, and gift shop. Call (907) 895-4270 for availability or reservations. Paid $45 for one night with 30 amp service, owner stated 50 amp site is $50.

name: Adventures on the Gorge
description: We stayed overnight in the campground and stopped here to dump our potty. There is a very clean area to fill potable water and dump tanks. There is no one around so I would gather you could use this for free even if you didn’t stay here. There is a lot to do here and in the area.

name: Superior YMCA
description: $3 showers - nice hot water! You do have to fill out a form with your contact info first.

name: Riverside
description: As you are coming down La Barge creek road headed west you’ll pass a cattle guard, a quick left turn will follow you down the creek on a dirt road. (There are also pre-existing fire rings at this point.) Easy road that an average car or rig could manage but trails very very close to the water so if you are wide or came after a big rain the road could be effected. This camp spot is as far as you can go before crossing the river. At the time we were here it was just over knee deep and we didn’t feel like risking it even in our high clearance vehicle but the road does continue further. However the spot right at the crossing is amazing, it sits between two rivers/creeks so you have water flowing on all three sides of you, there is a beaver dam that separates the two and if you’re lucky you’ll spot the little guys running around. There is a nice sized pre existing fire ring and just enough bush coverage for some shade.  No reception for AT&T or Verizon

name: Forest Park Campground
description: 14 sites and a self service campground. Didn’t stay, just drove through. No camp host and nobody occupying it when we drove through. They offer pit toilets and garbage cans. Otherwise typical campground. Didn’t check the fee.

name: Nenana public library
description: We parked yesterday afternoon in front of the library to use the fast wifi and kept on working ‘till late . We decided to stay here for the night. Village is super quiet and the night was quiet as well.

name: Hortons Pond
description: Small lake access site with room for a van or small bus to boondock. Public trash can and no other signage. A little road noise, otherwise quiet. No facilities. Parked without issue.

name: Truck parking lot
description: Semi trucking parking lot next to McDonald’s. Has dumpsters

name: Fish cleaning station
description: This fish cleaning station has an operational water faucet. I filled my van quickly. The marina is open, but the boat launch is closed. So the area is semi-deserted.

name: Rest Stop
description: There are water spigots at each of the stone water fountains that are right by the parking area. There wasn’t a ton of people so I was able to pull right up to the curb to fill up. You will need a hose longer than 10 feet to reach it. This was an awesome find as I am very low on water!

name: Lincoln Trailhead
description: Coordinates are a bit off but you’ll see the sign for Lincoln Trailhead once you turn down Olie street. Stayed 2 nights w/one other car. Rules are listed for trail use and camping. No one bothered me and no ranger stopped by. Extremely quiet except for the birds and bugs at night. Long parking spaces. No dumping, trash or amenities but it is FREE and so is the nearby National Park.

name: Virginia River Dam Overlook
description: Take the paved road from Hwy 9 south. Watch for the power poles. Those show the road. A couple hundred yards down is a dirt road on the left, take that, drive past a few camp sites and it will curve back to the right. This site (and several others) are right on the canyon rim overlooking the dam. Breezy, low dust. Strong cell service. TMobile really fast internet.

name: Little Gallagher Creek
description:
FREE
One spot very close to road but no privacy at all.
Another smaller, not for big rigs or trailers (ideal for tents and smaller vehicles) private and shaded spot +- 50m along the narrow track. Easy access to creek from here.

name: Stanley Ranger Water and Dump Station
description: Stanley ranger station dump station and drinking water. The dump station is $5 but the water is free.

name: Free BLM land next to river
description: Free BLM sites along the Arkansas River.  Metal fire rings but that is it. It is a very hot area but o w can climb down the river to wade or fish. The highway is across the river but is pretty quiet at night. Down the road is an established, paid campground,  Point Barr, $28 a night with a DAILY vehicle fee of $9. We walked through but nobody was here. Completely empty. But very nice.

name: Dump station adventures on the gorge
description: We stayed overnight in the campground and stopped here to dump our potty. There is a very clean area to fill potable water and dump tanks. There is no one around so I would gather you could use this for free even if you didn’t stay here. There is a lot to do here and in the area.

name: RV Ranch
description: AT&T and T-mobile have very good signal. 50 amp with full hookups. Spaces are 40 foot wide by 100 foot deep, enough room for the largest rigs. No pull throughs. Quiet place far enough away from city lights to see the stars at night. Beautiful views of the surrounding mountains that provide some awesome sunsets.

name: Cracker Barrel
description: So nice!  We always eat a meal and say thanks. Park on the side away from the Chucky Cheese.

name: Rocky Gap Rest area
description: Great place with grills, bathrooms, vending machines and plenty of oversize parking.

name: Three Bear Convenience Store
description: New gas & diesel station, propane & dump. Credit card pay to unlock at dump station.

name: Off street parking
description: There are three parking places off the overlook of the cliff. This is a great spot. There is no signs prohibiting parking and someone told me there is no-one that will bother you here because the tribe does not monitor these spots. The view is awesome but the spots are only good for vans and cars. We spent one night here just up the hill from head beach and it was nice. It has a slight slope but not bad. Enjoy

name: Near ranger station parking
description:
Moderator Note: Please confirm that camping is legal here.

There are 6 parking spots near road. They are good for vans and cars. Trail heads all around and one is Mirror Falls Creek. This is a great spot with no signs and you can wake up late since most people think you are hiking. Traffic during day but quiet at night. You can also can walk to the lake.

name: Street Parking
description:
Moderator Note: Please confirm that street parking is legal here.
.....
This is a quiet side street at top of 2nd street and  Laurel st.  No signs prohibiting and it just looks like you are parked for Comfort Inn hotel. Good for vans or smaller rvs, trucks and cars.

name: Spud Drive In Theater
description: Spuds Drive In Theater is our campsite for tonight. We watched a movie and asked if we could just stay the night and they told us $20 but we talked them into $10 if we told others so not a bad deal. Good spot for vans.

name: Hospital side street
description: Just found a nice side street next to hospital after checking out the Napoleon dynamite movie spots here in Preston, Idaho. This spot is in a quiet neighborhood so stealth mode would be advised for smaller Rv and vans.

name: Allis Park dump station
description: Free dump station halfway to the entrance from the road.

name: Brownies Hostel and Bakery
description: $1.75 per wash/dry load. Also $7 showers with unlimited time/private room. The cafe next door (Brownies) has pretty cheap food, $5-7 breakfast sandwiches/burritos and $10 sandwiches. They have wifi as well, with an outdoor patio.

name: Bald Knob Lookout
description: Resurrected 1962 Aircraft Warning Service Observation Station.  Located in the Rogue River-Siskiyou National Forest.  The lookout offers visitors a unique look lodging experience and panoramic views.  You can enquirer about lodging at Recreation.gov. OR get additional info at the Powers Ranger District at 42861 Hwy 242 , Powers, OR  97466 (541)439-6200

name: Surrey RV park
description: City park RV area next to a ballpark. Electric hookup, water & dump station. I believe you have to get in touch with a city worker to unlock them. We dry-camped in June & we’re the only ones here. Picnic tables & fire rings at each site. About 10 spaces. Room for big rigs but no pull through. Grass area for tents also. Bathrooms/showers are at the ballpark which is a short walk away. Have to call ahead for code into the shower room. Heard there is a pizza place & pub in this small town.

name: Rest Area
description: There are about three access points for water, the one we used is located at the end of the picnic areas.

name: Millers Landing Park
description: Drinking fountain near parking lot with lower nozzle good for filling water jugs.

name: Strawberry Creek Road
description: Large site with plenty of space for all types of rigs. pretty leveled too.can hear a small creek nearby

name: Furrier’s Tire Shop
description: Aligned the wheels on my 136 inch wheelbase Promaster (Fiat Ducato) van 21 feet (6.5 meters) in length.  9’3” (2.8 meters) in height. Not many alignment shops in Tucson could do this. Fast efficient and $110.

name: Deer Road Camping Area
description: primitive camping. No water,electric or facilities. Right next to the lake. Great view.

name: Gila NF Dispersed
description: Medium large site along Signal Creek Rd. Found level spot for 36’ MoHo. No cell signal. 7340’ elevation

name: Dirt Pulloff in Sand Dune
description: Big Pulloff near the street, but has enough distance to the Route 66. Not so much traffic at night, only the train. Quiet and no one bothered us. More or less level. About 5 or more places for big Campers

name: Ocoee lake highway pull off
description:
nice lakefront spot with picnic table near swim and fishing area. no posted signs stayed one night
more good overnight pull off spots up and down the road. most have picnic tables. some on the Ocoee River east of there might be better just for day parking but no no parking signs and plenty of spaces. busses dropping off rafts use ones further east on 64 so might be gone early if overnighting.
one of about 4 nice big rig no problem pull off spots Along road on Ocoee lake. no signs about camping. stayed one night do to other campgrounds in the area being full. It was a very nice spot with a picnic table. Not crazy about camping so close to the highway or parking so close to the highway but traffic slow down when it got dark and turned out to be a great night

name: Showers and Laundromat at Vitus Gas Station
description: Clean showers for $5 for 20 minutes, you have to pay inside tha gas station. There are washers ($5) and dryers ($2.5) available.

name: Laundromat at Vitus Gas Station
description: New washers ($5) and dryers ($2.5). Also shower is abailable for $5 for 20 minutes.

name: Plateau Parking Lot - Stealth Camping
description:
Came across this parking lot while visiting the National Harbor on a last-minute whim. This is a large uncovered parking lot that offers overnight parking. I travel in a minivan but saw a sprinter and small RV when I stayed over.  

This location is close to everything in National Harbor, so you basically have access to anything.

name: Kingston Canyon Rec Area
description: Nice level recreation area.  Parking, atv trails, pit toilets, tables and shade. Even a creek to fish. Some cell service.

name: Valley Overlook
description: Nice quiet spot that could fit several vehicles. Great view of the valley and Frazier Creek. Small dirt road turn off with some close pine branches.

name: Fox Homestead
description: One of four permitted campsites in High Rock Canyon, this is the northernmost one. This is also the site of the High Rock Garage, which can provide some shelter in a storm. Possible to hike west along Yellow Rock Canyon following a closed off road. No cell service.

name: Quaking Aspen Spring
description: Nice shady campsite just west of Quaking Aspen Spring. Looks out across a big meadow. Spring is fenced off. Lots of good camping uphill to the east as well.

name: Street parking Albany high school
description: The front is a high school but back around there is a park. Street parking all around. Very quiet residential neighborhood. The park has bathrooms open all night and a little outside kitchen with water. There is also an xfinity hot spot near the front entrance of the school. The pool is open in the mornings for public use and has showers but I don’t know the fee. I’ve parked here a few nights one night at a time with no issues. Over size vehicles are against city ordinances so long term parking isn’t an option

name: Pleasant Hill Park
description: 24 hour park with no signs that say you cant overnight.  I stayed the whole night no problems.  When I woke up there were about 7 other cars still parked as well.  Was a bit noisy til around 9-10 because people were still at the park.  Also had some street noise.

name: San Pedro Valley Park
description: An unpaved open space with picnic tables, water faucets and some shade trees. No signs prohibiting overnight parking. The negatives are: no trash cans, no toilets and most of the hard packed dirt is on a slope. Traffic noise abated late at night.

name: pull off at the side of the road
description: Pull off to the side of the forest road. No amenities. Verizon 3 bars. Vehicles are passing by.

name: Grizzly Campground
description: This forested Jackson County campground has 21 sites, vault toilets, and no hookups. The campground is on the shore of Howard Prairie Lake an there is a boat ramp, however it's currently closed due to low water levels.

name: Mountain Spirit Inn
description: Small (seven room) motel with regular car parking spaces in front of the rooms, at the south end of Darby, on the 93, on the way up to Chief Joseph Pass. Clean and comfortable rooms. Good, friendly management. $115 per night. Good for bikers/cyclists/cars/small vans. Only dogs. No other pets.

name: Surveyor Campground
description: Small, quiet, primitive BLM campground in the forest off of Keno Access Road. Sign says Surveyor Recreation Site but some maps call it Surveyor Mountain Campground.

name: Walmart/Abandoned lot
description: Behind a Walmart parking lot. Empty gravel lot. Nice and quiet and I didn't have an issue for 2 nights. One other van parked there who looked like they were there long term.

name: Macon county fair grounds camp grounds
description: full hookup $20 a night level sites real quiet and safe area

name: By dry creek bed
description: Nice spot for an overnight right off highway. Trees and slight distance help block noise from highway. Stay in the open field or near the creek bed in the trees.   If you go into the dry creek or dry reservoir it’s deep sand and you’ll need 4wd and/or to air down as if on a beach.   There was a larger camper staying in the field so larger rigs can stay there.  Plenty of room.

name: the dog that barks
description:
Nice spot on National Forest Service land. But further up this road and you get to private. two fire rings and far enough off the main road that you can't hear it. Close to Wind Cave.

earlier in the night there was quite a bit of dogs barking but that all seemed to settle by 11.

good fi has full LTE bars but no 5g

name: Earl’s Laundromat
description: Small laundromat, nothing special. Easy access and room to park bigger rigs.

name: Elk Horn RV Park
description: Water $3, Dump $5. Easy access. Right off of AZ 260.

name: Dispersed Campsites
description: Another 13 dispersed campsites 1 mile further down from the 11 Dispersed campsites already noted. I didn’t drive into the campground but I took a photo of the sign at the entrance. I don’t know how the road is or what the campsites look like. Hopefully someone can update this after they check the area out.

name: Knob and Goober Lake camping
description: we drove to the end of this road last night and stayed at the very top near the radio tower. There are turnouts all down the road with rock fire pits.  The views are great! There are several lakes to park by or go to the top and look down at all of the lakes.  We didn't see any mosquitoes and had decent cell service with T-Mobile.

name: Pretty forest campsite no cell
description: Dirt road manageable 2WD and normal clearance. If you go further the road is pretty bad ( and there is another site, but the road is horrible). Really pretty and almost leveled. Fire pit. Sunny and shady. Enough far from the road to let our pet going freely

name: The Park
description: Newly renovated RV park with brand new electrical at all 23 rv sites including water and sewer

name: Jean Sweeney Open Space Park
description: 24 hour park with no signs that say you can’t overnight.  I (and another vehicle). Stayed the night with no issue.  In a pretty quiet area and the park is really nice.  Has bathrooms open during the day and a water fountain.

name: Two Dispersed Spots with Tent Sites
description: Another pull off large enough for a couple vans. If you follow the trail down the hill you will come to a small meadow with a few tent sites surrounding it. There is a small fire ring by the parking spots, and a larger fire ring down at the meadow. Barely any cell service(2 bars -118db from cell sites in Durango.)

name: Small BLM spot off road to Bodie
description: At the gravel pull-out posted on the Bodie road take the second gravel road (on the notice-board side of the pull-out) into the desert BLM land. A short way down there is a small space suitable for something 24ft or less. We parked our 23ft Class C here for one night, it wasn't that level but it was fine for us. It's probably flatter on the pull-out but we didn't want to be too close to the road. Lovely sagebrush desert. Quiet, easy access for 2WD, no T-mobile signal.

name: Pulloff near Hemlock Cliffs
description: It's a wide spot on the side of Union Chapel Rd. heading towards Hemlock Cliffs trailhead.  This is on national forest land.  The spot was big enough for my Outback, but could fit a sprinter van.  Anything larger probably wouldn't fit.  No firepit or other facilities.  No cell service (at&t).  Camping and overnight parking are prohibited at the trailhead and on the road leading up to it.  These areas are clearly marked with signs.  There was a larger spot about half a mile further down on the right just before the road to the trailhead big enough to accommodate several rv sized rigs.  It was occupied by a good sized group when I got there.  The spot is quiet and I did have a bear come by while I was setting up for the night so be bear aware and secure your food and trash inside your rig.

name: June Lake Library
description:
Free wifi, can be accessed from the parking lot, which is right next to the lake too. 

I was able to work and do zoom calls effectively. Speed test has varried from 10-50mbps but has been consistently above 10.

name: Fireplace Day Area
description: Across the road from the day area is a sign that says camping and there are a couple of fire rings in the trees and some sort of level ground. Pit toilets across the road in the day area. 1 bar Verizon.

name: Grayson Getaways
description: 19 camp sites, with full sewage, water and electric (30 &50 amp) hookups, can take rigs up to 35 feet, accepts tent camping as well. 3 cabins for rent that sleep 4. Campground has bathrooms, showers, laundry, camp store, kayak and stand up paddle board rentals and tours! Campsites are $35 a night.

name: Boat Launch near Goodell Creek Campground
description: Small parking lot for the boat launch near Goodell Creek Campground. No signs saying overnight parking is not permitted. I stayed one night with no issues. Very quiet. Could hear the Creek all night. Zero bars TMobile. 3bars LTE on Verizon.

name: Water refill station inside the North Cascades Visitor center
description: Water jug/bottle refill station, inside the North Cascades Visitor Center. It is only accessible during operating hours.

name: Davenport Park
description: Threaded water spigot on southeast corner of picnic shelter in Davenport Park. Not close enough to a parking area to refill a fixed tank but could fill Jerry cans or similar.

name: Dave’s hollow dispersed campsites
description:
You can now camp in Dave’s Hollows! The catch is that you have to be in designated campsites which are numbered. Stay up to 16 days. 

It is a a OHV use road/loop. Roads are rutted.

name: Eureka City Park
description: City of Eureka South Dakota has RV park in its City Park.  Electric (30 and 50 amp available) at all sites. Drinking water, dump station, SHOWERS, picnic tables, indoor pavilion, playground, lake and even an underground tornado shelter. $25 per night. I arrived on a Monday and had place to myself. When I arrived, there was a motorhome packing up. They said they were the only ones there over the weekend.  Small grocery store as well as gas station are in town.

name: H2O at Lions Pavilion in Confluence Park
description: Water comes out of the spigot attached to the drinking water fountain. No threads for a hose but it’s potable water.

name: Western Inn Motel & RV Park
description: Cheap Potable Water at RV Park. We filled up our 30 gallon tank for 3 dollars. Park in one of the parking spaces in the front and talk to the folks inside. Super nice people!!

name: dump station on side of road, not potable flush water
description: Dump station on the side of road on the way to blm snake river spots. Asks for 1 dollar donation and has flush water with a hose. I didn't need to use it so I cannot attest to it's functionality.

name: At the Lake near entrance Yosemite np
description: Nice place at the Lake. With table. At the creek and Lake. Good Spot.

name: Valley of the Moon
description: Just off i-8 is a dirt track called valley of the moon. It is frequented by border patrol but otherwise I haven’t seen anyone here. This pin is where it starts to get rough, we didn’t proceed in our Delica. Any stock 4x4 would be fine to get this far. A few pull outs along the way. The road is on Gaia. Check out the short hike to smugglers den. Decent Verizon signal.

name: Exit Glacier (Tent only) campground
description: This is a tent only campground within the national park. Google said it was free. There is a community picnic area and restrooms. The sign coming in said "tents only, no RVs". There was one other vehicle when I got here at 9pm.

name: Glacier toe Overlook
description: Great overlook of the Salmon glacier toe and the river. We tried to get up to the proper overlook but the bulldozers had the road blocked and we’re clearing the snow. Impassable today and a few more days perhaps. We turned around and found this wide overlook. Not a bad place to make due. We are here early season with very few people on the road. Fallen logs on the road but passable yo this point. Campers, motor homes and cars all traveling this far. There is a garbage bin here, a small waterfall making noise beside us, a lovely view of the river below and the toe of Glacier. No cell service. We set up our Starlink for service.

name: Dart In Laundromat
description: Laundromat beside Sinclair fuel station. There are about 6 washers and 20 dryers.

name: Patterson Lake Recreation Area
description: Grassy campsites next to a lake in Dickinson. They are on even grass spaces in a huge park with picnic tables and fire pits. $18 / night for pit toilet + dumpster but for $10 more dollars you get dump, water, electric hookups, flush toilets, and showers. You can reserve on their website or go to the entrance directly.

name: Dead road near freeway
description: Quiet dead road with beautifull sunrise and totally dark night. We parked our motorhome in a dirt road sorrounded of horses.

name: Small walmart
description: Small walmart little noise. Has a frange of grass and tables.

name: Freeport Village Campground
description:
*they only take CASH or CHECK* 
Cheapest place that I could find around this area. It is a couple miles off of 1-295. I called ahead at the visitor center and they said they had one spot available. It is $44 full hook up (water, sewer, electric) at each site. They have a laundry facility, little free library (books & DVD’s), pool (they just opened it when I got here), wifi (was not working when I got there and from other people it sounds like it usually isn’t working), showers, bathroom, & a kitchen. The people working the campground were not very helpful and basically only had me sign a piece of paper and take my money. They did not tell me about the amenities or where to find anything. I found them not super hospitable.
*FRONT DESK CLOSES AT 6pm so make sure you can get in before then. 
With all that said I am not recommending this place. It is a great place for a night to dump tanks, do laundry, etc but other than that I would not stay here just to stay here. It is a pretty quiet campground with mostly older people that are here for awhile.

name: Amtrak/Greyhound
description:
I found this spot by a miracle when I was trying to find a place to park my 31ft Class C so we could go to the beach. We didn’t plan on spending the night, but I met Sanford and he’s been parked here for 18 months. This is NOT Santa Barbara County, but federal property because it’s Amtrak/Greyhound. Sanford was a great “park host.” He’s parked in the corner on the Greyhound lot, tell him Jason and Kristin sent you. He wants good families and people to keep the bad guys away. 
You can dump for FREE at Marborg Industries - 728 E Yanonali St
Santa Barbara, CA 93103.
And propane at U-Haul, they also let it’s fill our water.

name: Huskins Branch campground
description: This is where the actual campground is at Fire's Creek.  nice campground.  probably just for tents but I found a few nice places for my 32ft motorhome.  very peaceful and primitive.  small creek and stone fire pits.

name: US Forestry Road
description: Tucked away just off two main drags, easy to get to, flat ground, and good for jeep or Venus. fire pit could fit 2-3 around it comfortably. nice location, quiet, slightly visible from both main roads in the winter due to lack of leaves.

name: NF 5200
description: A little creek beside more water, nice spot in the NF. worked well for the evening. established fire pit as well.

name: Creekside
description: By the creek off to the side of a trail/path/road with an established fire pit. the Creek is crystal clear. pack it out and be considerate! there was a fire can in the NF, be mindful of that. the road had zero passersby and had gorgeous sounds and views of the cold Creek.

name: Fred Endert Municipal Pool
description: $6 for day use gives you access to the pool, hot tub, sauna, etc (as their schedule allows) and shower. the showers are NOT private so be confident or bring a swimsuit! you can take as long as you want, provided the locker rooms aren’t busy. the water pressure is good and the temp is hot but it does take some time to heat up. staff is nice and locker room was clean. it’s probably not the ideal shower for most, but it’s a shower!

name: Flying J Travel Center
description: $10 RV dump. Enter in on the auto side and then go to the far side of the building towards the truck pumps and you'll see a sign.

name: South Yuba campground
description: South Yuba campground near trail - pit toilets, large spots with picnic tables & firepits. The road getting up here is pretty rough but it’s a nice spot. $5 per night

name: Lincoln gulch dispersed site #3
description:
Nice camp site off the road 
Big enough for three cars
Lots of firewood and trees to hang hammocks in 
Food storage to keep the bears out!!

name: Forest site off 82
description:
Cute little site next to river.
Did some panning for gold just for fun.
Lots of trees for shade and for hanging hammocks.
My husband build a nice fire pit
Smaller vehicles only 
Some wildlife (deer and elk) 
Pretty flat spot 
Can see cars off the road but not a big deal 

Happy camping

name: Saint Margaret Mary’s Church
description:
The parking lot of St. Margaret Mary’s Church is right off of 61st and Dodge St., across from the University Nebraska at Omahas campus. There are UNO local police and UNO security driving in the area but not through the church parking lot.

Safety: I’ve stayed here a few nights and have not been woken up by police or security. I have left around 10am each time and the parking lot is not busy. I am unsure if the church is 24 hrs and if the door is open in the evening for access to the bathroom. However, there are two close by gas stations within a mile or so. The parking lot is lit however if you prefer a darker sleeping area, closer to the end of the parking lot near the trees provides a less lit area. There is not broken glass on the ground in the parking lot (unlike Zorinsky Lake) so break ins do not seem frequent. 

Scenery: Elmwood Park and Memorial Park are within walking distance which is a relaxing area to walk pets or hammock. There is a line of trees that separate the parking lot from Dodge St. so the noise of traffic is not unbearable. 

Food: Being right on Dodge St. accessibility to food is easy and a variety is all within a mile (pizza, ramen, Mediterranean, curry, Chinese, fast food).

name: Pet Wash Express
description: Nice set up. It is in pet food warehouse. $12 a dog. They provide shampoo, towels etc

name: Sar-Ko-Par Park
description:
Nice area for dogs to stretch legs. Water fountains for dogs.
 Water spouts to refill rig. bathrooms.

name: Bergen Park and Ride
description: Some minor traffic noise but really not that bad. The huge park behind it makes up for it. It’s huge and fun to explore. A few other vans parked here for the night with no problems. Safe and worth the drive off I-70. Grocery stores and restaurants within walking distance. Excellent AT&T service

name: Chevron - Propane
description: The Chevron gas station is selling propane.

name: Craggy Gardens Picnic Area
description: tap water at the picnic area restrooms, there are also water pumps within the area. perfect place to rest and have lunch

name: Walmart
description: local police recommend as a safe overnight spot.

name: Little Duck Key Wayside
description: This area is explicitly marked NO OVERNIGHT CAMPING but the police officer that told us to leave the McDonald's advised us to park here. probably a temporary place they have chosen to turn a blind eye to.

name: I 90 eastbound rest area mile marker 8
description: Very busy rest area - gas - food - bathrooms. You can stay overnight but it is right off the freeway. truck area can hold larger RV’s. Vans can find flat areas in the car parking area

name: Spot by the river
description: Single area right on the river. Big gravel open area with good sun and a stone fire pit. Enough room for any but the largest rigs to turn around, however the short double-track path from the main road is very narrow and tight. River is quite loud here, but lovely!

name: Vistus
description: chepeast gas, Diesel, propane, also laundry and shower,very nice staff

name: McDonald Lake
description:
A truly beautiful spot next to a lake, it’s about 5 miles east of Highway 93 via a turning called Lake McDonald Rd, around 4 miles north of St Ignatius.  The road is unpaved but in good condition and no issue for 2WD vehicle / standard car.
It was recommended to us by a local and overnight parking is allowed.
Public toilets are here.
One other rig here during our stay.
We had 1 bar of Verizon & T-Mobile signal here.

Around 4pm the next day a conservation officer arrived & explained the need for a camping permit costing $100 each.  Apparently this site in within an Indian Reservation & permits must be purchased in advance simply just to park there in the daytime.
We moved on.

name: Lower Mill Creek
description: Small pull-off for 2-3 vehicles. We made it up in a 5-window short bus so 4WD and high clearance is not needed

name: Golden Shower
description: There is a water spigot underneath the 2 hour parking sign. There was no one to ask, but we used it without any issues.

name: Steamboat Springs Overlook
description: Gravel Pulloff with an amazing view of the valley. Not the flattest, but worth it for the sunset

name: Vigils Iron Works LLC
description:
James Vigil Jr. is a very good place for steel fabrication, diesel mechanics and custom work. They mounted our new suspension in really good time.
195 camino de la Merced, Taos NM 87571. Shop (575)751 0390 Fax (575)737 0878
Very friendly service!

name: Dope ocean view overlook spot
description: Awesome place to park the van, look at the ocean, hear the waves.. get out of the car even or go on top of the van and watch the sunset muy bonita

name: Kill Devil Coin Laundry
description:
Decent laundry mat. Was not busy, plenty of parking I even found a shady spot which is hard to do in the Outer Banks. 
And as an added bonus there’s a water Spicket on the side of the building, the left side of the building as you’re facing it.

name: Lake Easton Sno-Park
description: The Lake Easton day use area allows single vehicle camping and tenting in its day use area in the winter. The boat ramp area allows trailers. As of 2022, the cost is $12. A snow park pass is also required for xcountry skiing.

name: Crystal Springs Sno-park
description: Winter camping only while the sno-park is open. Lot 4 is for campers who do not have motorized recreation vehicles (aka snowmobiles). There is no nightly charge but you must have a snow pass.

name: Lis-bon Acres
description:
This is a sanctuary that has 3 camping spots. U have to call ahead. They r on hipcamp and harvest hosts. 
You can also find “Lis-bon Acres” contact info on Facebook. 
Very friendly and u get to feed/pet the animals. Has a little playground for the kids and a meditation area. 
Also has glamping (a spacious canvas tent with wooden roof).

name: Lincoln State Park Dump Station
description: Single dump station at park entrance. Fresh water available but u have to pull forward

name: Grover community park
description:
Red spigot next to the parking.
Good flow. May not be potable.

name: Loves travel stop
description: I slept really good this night I had no issues and I parked far over by the taco johns. There is plenty rv parking but I came in a truck and there were a few  other car sleepers.

name: Quiet River #2
description: On the other side of the river. Take the big bridge and go to the left. Big flat area. There’s a fire pit. Lots of room. A few broken down vehicles. No signs saying no camping.

name: Shell/McDonalds
description: Red water spigot off to the left of McDonalds. Not heavy pressure, but water is working.

name: Bear Creek TH
description: Parking lot for Bear Creek Trail. There were no “No overnight Parking “ signs. Just adjacent to highway, but was quiet overnight. Very level.

name: Pet Hollow Road
description: Follow road down half a mile until you find a turn around. Level ground. Quiet and secluded. You can occasionally hear a car during the day. Completely silent at night. Great for walking dogs. Good hikes. No service for Verizon. 1 bar of LTE for AT&T

name: Gorgeous views-remote road
description: Remote dirt road that goes far back (SE Grizzly rd). Pull offs along it and this one is up on a steep hill but relatively flat when you get there. Big rigs wouldn’t be able to come up to this spot. Gorgeous views. A couple vehicles past late at night but didn’t bother us. 2-3 bars of Verizon.

name: street parking (Van's only)
description: I found this spot in rolling Meadows,  lots of car and trucks parked. street light at night with some road noise.  You would have to be stealth to park here. no signs says not parking. other vehicles has been sitting for days.

name: mountain camping
description: I found this spot up the mountain.  looks like no one really comes up here. I have 4 bars of the mobile 5g with wiBoost 20 mbs. So I guess I'll be up here for a while . ***note, the road is very hard to get up if your rig is big. I made it going slow. I have a 93 G20 with all terrain tires

name: Flintlock Campground
description: Beautiful mountain campsite. Full, partial hook up, cabins + primitive. Waterfall creek. WiFi. Clean bathrooms w hot showers. Laundry room.

name: Sugarland Run Landromat
description: Not a ton of parking but one of the only places to do laundry in the area. 7-11 is next door for gas and snacks while you wait for your clothes to dry.

name: South Woody Mountain Road
description: After residential houses, nice place next to the wood, very quiet (we stay here because the others spots are closed du to the forest fire). Recommanded by local. 3 signal barres and 4g

name: Forest Turnout
description: From the forest Road, take the first right and drive until you get to a turnout. Easy access, any car can make it. Better for Cars, Campervan or small RVs. Surrounded by trees, so very private. Little Road noise but not too much.

name: Cenex Truck Stop/ Gas station
description:
12$ per person. 
Too much for me, so I didn't shower here, but good to know.

name: Playground/Picnicspot
description:
This is an area with playground, beachvolleyballfield, 4 barbecues, 9 or 10 shaded picnic tables , trash cans and a restroom with running water and even electricity to charge your phone( we didn't try it but the light works at night). Maybe the locals of the little city nearby have a barbecue here sometimes?
Awesome view over meadows and the hills of the area. Saw some deer, lots of mosquitos in the evening. Really peacefull and awesome stars!
No signs at all, neither only day use nor no camping. We stayed from ca. 8pm to 11:30am and no one even came around.
As this seems to be a spot belonging to the city/village I would not recommend staying with large campervans or tents, seems a bit unfriendly to me. There were some animals howling close by in the evening, don't know if dogs are a good idea here.

name: Quaking Aspen Nook
description:
The road ahead was closed so I found a pull off, the area could hold 4 or so vans, then there's a huge clearing with room for dozens of tents if the season was right. 

stayed overnight, no problem, there's a tiny inn 5 minutes down the road. quiet as the app. currently sipping on seltzer and reading while my dog guards the van and smells literally everything

name: Volunteer Canyon
description: Entrance area to volunteer canyon.  About a mile north of Stinson Beach on CA highway 1, on Bolinas Lagoon. Spent the night there April 17, 2021. Highway noise not a problem. None at all after about 9:00, very quiet all night, otters playing in the Lagoon in the early morning. Don’t really know the local rules but no one bothered us.

name: Antelope Hill
description: Just south of Antelope Hill, off 171. Two campsites, great view of Antelope Hill. Adequate solar exposure. Easy in for any vehicle. Grazing cows are a nice touch.

name: public lot at Unicorn and Dye St
description: this is a paid public parking lot. select RV/camper at the pay meter, pay $20 and enjoy parking through the next calendar day.

name: Food 4 Less
description: Glacier machines outside of Food 4 Less. $0.35 per gallon.

name: Big Joshua Tree
description:
Dirt road (moderate lose sand, but 2wd seems ok on dry days). Leads to a gorgeous big Joshua tree with a area to park for one or two vehicles. 
2 bar cell with Verizon.

name: Premium fresh water
description: Water machines build into the wall.  35c per gallon.

name: AT&T good cell
description: Just marking this spot next to the grass field as a place that had a strong AT&T cell reception. Small area to park next to road. Not good for camping, but ok for working if you need cell.

name: Verizon cell Zion
description: Marking this place since it has two bars verizon. Pretty fast. Ok for working. But this is a small parking on side of road. Not ok for camping

name: Deschutes NF BLM Starlink
description: The same Deschutes NF BLM land as previous added, but I am marking this open spot half the route because there is good Starlink internet here. (The rest of the forest has relatively poor cell)

name: lowes parking lot
description: lowes parking lot, no "no overnight parking" signs. nobody bothered us and they have free wifi! bathrooms availabke during the day but not over night.

name: Bridger-Teton National Forest
description: This spot is fantastic. It's the final campsite up the hill and has a great view of the Tetons. Multiple vehicles can stay in one spot. Beautiful and free. Camping has to be done in designated spots and there are restrictions for RVs. Only 30 minutes (depending on which part you come from) from Grand Teton National Park.

name: Ridge top above hot springs
description: Definitely need high clearance and likely 4WD, but the views are great. Surprisingly buggy up here, but I don’t know how normal that is. 3 bars LTE on ATT.

name: Mobil
description: Water spigot on the side of the building! Right next to the Cracker Barrel - convenient if you also want to park here for the night.

name: Freeport Library
description: Free wifi that you can get from the parking lot. The wifi is FCL-Public no passcode needed. There is also free public wifi at the outlet mall.

name: Off i80
description: Behind a power station, within 15 min of i80 depending on which road your map takes you, much quieter than the other sites near by, gravel patch but easy for any vehicle

name: Ashley national forest
description: We are currently here right now - update this tomorrow. Super easy - gassed up at the pilot a mile and a half away (approximately) roll in found a spot!!! Perfect National Forest spot for traveling through Flagstaff!!!

name: YNP close Entrance
description: Only a few miles out of town Good view, and just past cemetery.

name: dry Creek campground
description:
Alaska state recreational area with 50 campsites, some pull through sites. $20 per campsite 
restrooms, water, fishing and trails

name: WalMart
description: Typical WalMart with the exception of the dirt bikes that rode round and round our rig for 20 minutes at 4:45 am.

name: Glacier Campground
description:
Feels like you’re in the mountains. Pretty campground. Great restaurant. $62 a night. 
Electric and water. Dump is by the office on your way out. 
Glacier NP is expensive so this wasn’t bad considering the area and convenience.

name: Longmont Recycling Center
description: Single sort recycling is before of gated area. Behind gate is more in-depth recycling for residents of the town.

name: Cecil Village Park
description: Sanitation dump and water fill up. $5 fee. Could be a little tricky fitting in for bigger rigs.

name: Flagstaff Arizona
description: Awesome place. We’re up 1.8 miles from the Pilot trucks-top -  in the national forest - perfect place to stay while traveling on interstate 40.

name: Stanley Lake Campground
description:
Beautiful campground with several gravel camping loops and a total of 39 sites overlooking Lake Stanley and Mt McGowan in the Sawtooth Range. Sites are large and private with gravel pad, picnic table, and a fire pit. All sites are dry camping, no hookups. There are several water pumps for filling jugs but no hose connection to fill an RV. Pit toilets, trash cans and recycling. There is a boat ramp and courtesy life preservers are available. There are also hiking trails in the park. A lake trail that goes around the lake and several hikes into the Sawtooth Wilderness begin here. 1 MTB ride, Elk Mt, starts at the trailheads and 3 more MTB trails on forest roads that begin directly across Stanley Lake entrance on Hwy 21. Maps for all trails are available at the Stanley Visitor Center.

To get to Stanley Lake Campground from Stanley take Hwy 21 west about 5-6 miles. 1/2 mile past Stanley RV Park turn left onto Stanley Lake Road. Follow the paved road for 3 miles to the Campground and follow the signs. Sites can be reserved. If not it's first come basis. Host will come by your campsite to collect $20/night. Firewood is $10. Checkout is 1pm.

name: East Allen Lake
description: East Allen Lake in Medicine Bow National Forest. Nicely maintained gravel road with pit toilets. Access through private land as noted on sign. 5 day camping limit. Cellphone reception is very good.

name: Cherokee RV Campground
description: Dump Station with cleaning water to rinse your tanks’ hose.

name: Jordan Valley Park
description: Hose Bibb available...left side of field near parking lot fence.

name: Free BLM designated spots ON the river!
description:
Free BLM sites on the river. Site called The Hill. Most sites are park on road and walk in to sites with tables and rings. Shady and gorgeous, 
14 day limit. Porta johns at end of road in parking lot. Drive down the road in the opposite direction for more BLM sites.

Trust me, big rugs will not fit here. Try Tunnel cg down the road.

name: Peterson RV Park (skoolies can park there)
description:
Peterson, MN 55962
This is a really small but nice place to park with hookups- electrical and water. Skoolies can park there. I believe the longest motorhome I can park. there is a 40 ft. It's gravel with some grass and there's a playground directly in front of the parking spaces. A lot of the neighborhood community uses the park. There are eight parking places and reservations are definitely recommended. It's $30 a night and cash only. But you need a credit card to make the reservation. there's a bathroom and a black tank dump available at the site. It is in a very small town so you do have to buy whatever you need before getting to town. Most businesses close very early. beautiful view of the mountains. really quiet. 

Wi-Fi - It's there and you can use it to watch videos. I was able to do basic work for my virtual job. But just barely. Verizon didn't work very well so I use the campground's Wi-Fi.

name: Small pull off, Seymour Creek Road
description:
Small pull off just big enough for one car (not big enough for a trailer probably). It’s effectively on the road, so isn’t at all private from passing cars.

There is a fire ring.

Cooler weather up here at elevation is nice when it gets hot down below.

name: Walmart Ames Iowa
description: Walmart parking lot. Only signs prohibiting semi’s. Very quiet back lot. Ames and Iowa State University are beautiful with lots to enjoy and eat in the area.

name: Gogebic boat launch east
description: Large level lot with boat access. Quiet place just off a tar county road. Here midweek and only one pickup with trailer in the lot. Little Verizon cell service. Surrounded by woods. Pit toilet next to launch area.

name: Kwik Trip
description: Kwik Trip with diesel and truck/ over sized rig parking right off I90 exit

name: Riverton Aquatic Center
description: Pools, hot tub, sauna, and showers available. $4 for a day pass. The aquatic center is attached to the high school but it's open to the public during certain hours of the day. Make sure to check online before going, as the hours are somewhat sporadic.

name: Radium hot spring BLM
description: Nice BLM close to a hiking Trail going to a natural hot spring.  A few place on the route to the head of the Trail they are easy to acces but not level.  We did sleep there, saw a group of big horn and a wild turkey. There are also few after place the trail but need high clearance to acces.  No water or toilet there.  Please leave no trace.

name: Grandjean campground
description: Nice Fire service camp with 31 sites. Tables, fire rings, bathroom, nice sites right near the river.  $18 nite- 1/2 with senior pass.

name: Base Camp at Golden Gate Canyon
description: At the base Camp gas station/campground there is a spigot to get water from to the right of the store. Just ask the store attendant if you need help. Water is 25¢/gallon (honesty policy). Bathrooms are right across from the spigot and they are really nice. Showers available too.

name: Small spot near Elk River Road
description: A small spot right next to the Elk River Road. Space for a small tent, not super level. Water running to the Elk river is a bit noisy. There is a fire pit but no cell service. Good for a night, no one disturbed us.

name: Visitor Center Parking
description: 2 hr motorhome and RV parking at the visitor center. The parking lot is one way so make sure you enter the right way.

name: FSR 669
description:
I dont often post my spots but South Park seems quite devoid of campsites. You have to go all the way through the ranch (follow signs for forest access and do not bother the residents!) 

FSR 669 was in fairly good condition, doable with a Honda Fit. I can tell this road could get messy after some rain, ruts from prvious trucks evident. 

lots of little spots along the side, some bits of shade, but GREAT service depending on the spot both ATT and VZ. cell tower visible from rise. Show fairplay some love, be kind, pass it on

name: Glacier Water Refill Station
description: 40¢ per gallon, $2 for 5 gallons. on the side of the Texaco gas station. we haven't seen any other water stations in this town so consider filling up if you are close to running out.

name: Jumbo campground
description: On the Grand Mesa. Very nice level sites. Run by a concessionaire for the USFS. Electricity available at many sites. reservations also available through recreation.gov. $30 /noc for electrical site.

name: Upper Large site Missionary Ridge Road
description: Large area near a closed gate just passed middle coon creek. Very nice spot without cell service. could fit a pretty big rig

name: flat pullout
description: A flat spot in the aspens where you can pull off the road. Probably fit a 30foot rig. Existing fire ring. no cell service

name: Corral Material Storage
description: several very large sites for horse trailers or big rigs. large material pile. Also additional large spots across the road. take a left off Missionary Ridge at the y before the gate

name: Trailhead parking and campsites
description: Parking for a short trail and a fire ring. Seems camping is permitted. Also another fire ring and flat spot good for tents on the other side of the road. no parking at this second spot.

name: BLM Del Norte
description: A nice flat open area very close to a cell tower.  There are numerous sites in the area.  This one is big enough for a small group.

name: Hidden Lake Campground
description: Campground with sites from Lake loop (waterfront) to Skyview loop (higher elevation. Vault toilets, hand pump water available. No AT&T coverage. Two lower CG loops have signs that state limited RV maneuvering, only Skyview loop bigger rig friendly.

name: Rooterville Animal Sanctuary
description: Rooterville provides a safe and compassionate refuge to rescued farm animals.  A Visit to Rooterville is Fun for the Whole Family - interact with the rescued animals, walk through the butterfly and bee garden, visit the gift shop,  and camp onsite! Visit Rooterville.org to find out about visiting hours and booking a stay.

name: Cottonwood Lake Campground
description:
13 sites near the lake.
No services, no fee.
Two toilets.

name: Rooterville Animal Sanctuary
description: Camping on site at the animal sanctuary! Must book in advance via website or phone. 2 glamping covered wagons, 2 RV hookup sites with 30/50 amp and water, and tent camping available. Phone service on ATT is pretty good.  Love it here!

name: On Top of the Hill Campspot
description:
Quite nice little Campspot in a State Forest. No Permit needed, no sign which forbids to camp here. Many other places are marked in this area for camping by iOverlander, but they didn't meet our expectations. We drove a little bit further and found a nice spot on top of a little hill. A hidden Place with enough space for a 2-3 Person Tent and Car or Motorbikes. 
Verizon had weak Signal but I was able to load Websites. 
Road to the Campspot only passable with small 4x4 Vehicle (no big trucks) or Adventurebikes.

name: Lower Stock Tank
description: Small parking area next to a newer stock tank. there is another older tank up the road a hundred yards. This tank is dry at the moment but it looks recently built. three bars of Verizon service here, but speeds are slow via a cell tower 13miles north.

name: Spic and Span
description: Laundromat with washers and dryers. free wifi

name: Pull off next to river
description: Wide gravel shoulder next to the river a few miles past Index, could fit quite a few vehicles/RV’s. No Verizon service. There is a fire ring and the river is beautiful. Almost no traffic because the road is permanently closed a few miles up. Looks like the spot *could* be a party spot for teenagers on the weekends judging by some graffiti and a few pieces of trash/bottles but I didn’t run into any issues here on a Tuesday night. The view is spectacular, mountains on every side and a rushing river to lull you to sleep.

name: Eagle Rock Aerie
description: A commanding position high above Rt 92 in the Gunnison Gorge National Conservation Area East of Delta, CO. The road in is rocky but should offer no trouble for most vehicles, but there are a couple of tight turns so towed vehicles not recommended. 4WD is not necessary. This site is about 1.25 miles in, but there are several sites along the way. Excellent AT&T.

name: Ruby Creek Expansive Gravel Lot
description:
Massive gravel area right next to Richardson Highway and the Ruby Creek Bridge. Entrance on north side of Ruby Creek.  Easy access, mostly level and tons of room for many rigs of any size. Bit of a walk out to the Delta River.
